document.masterDocTitle: Burrowing mud shrimps (Decapoda: Axiidea & Gebiidea) of the northeastern Black Sea and their external parasites

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Burrowing mud shrimps (Decapoda: Axiidea & Gebiidea) of the northeastern Black Sea and their external parasites

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
BLACK SEA : Crimean Peninsula : 2♂♂ ( ZMMU Ma-6197 and Ma-6198), 2 ovigerous ♀♀ ( ZMMU Ma-6199 and Ma-6200)— Kruglaya Bay (Omega), 44°35’51.8”N 33°26’40.8”E , depth
0.5–1.5 m
, burrows fine sand and sand with sea grass, with yabbi pump, coll. I. Marin ,
14.06.2020
;
5♂♂ , 7 ovigerous ♀♀ ( LEMMI )— same locality and date; 2♂♂ , 3 ovigerous ♀♀ ( LEMMI )— Kazachiya Bay , 44°34’10.8”N 33°24’47.1”E , burrows in fine sand and sand with sea grass, with yabbi pump, coll. I. Marin ,
10.06.2020
.

Remarks.
Gilvossius tyrrhenus
can be separated from the co-occurring congeneric
G. candidus
by the following morphological features ( Ngoc-Ho 2003 ): the peduncle of antenna I is slightly longer than the peduncle of antenna II in
G. tyrrhenus
(
Fig. 3 b
), while they are mostly equal in
G. candidus
(
Fig. 3 a
); the meral hook of the major cheliped in males is blunt distally in
G. tyrrhenus
(
Fig. 3 e, f
), rather than acuminate distally in
G. candidus
(
Fig. 3 c, d
); the dactylus of major chelipeds is almost equal to palm in length in
G. tyrrhenus
(
Fig. 3 e, f
), while it is significantly shorter than palm in
G. candidus
(
Fig. 3 c, d
); the carpus of major chelipeds in females is about 1.5 times longer than wide, widening distally in
G. tyrrhenus
(
Fig. 3 h
), while it is almost quadrate in
G. candidus
(
Fig.
3 g
); the carpus of the minor cheliped is wider proximally than distally and wider than the palm in
G. tyrrhenus
, whereas it is not wider proximally than distally and as wide as the palm in
G. candidus
; the border of the dorsal plate on the uropodal exopod is closer to the exopodal margin in
G. tyrrhenus
(
Fig. 2 h
) than in
G. candidus
(
Fig.
2 g
); the telson is about as long as wide in
G. tyrrhenus
(
Fig. 2 d, f
), while wider than long in
G. candidus
(
Fig. 2 c, e
). In addition to those morphological characters, the body size is larger in
G. candidus
than in
G. tyrrhenus
(tl. ( ♂ ) 81 mm in
G. candidus
vs. tl. ( ♂ ) 58 mm in
G. tyrrhenus
). The chelipeds are sometimes pinkish in
G. tyrrhenus
, rather than always white in
G. candidus
(see Fig. 1 ); the telson and uropods are also pinkish or yellowish in males of
G. tyrrhenus
( Figs 1 ;
2 h
), although they are always white in
G. candidus
( Figs 1 ;
2 g
). Ngoc-Ho (2003) also mentioned the color variation in
G. tyrrhenus
.

Parasites. Three of collected specimens of
G. tyrrhenus
were infested with the rhizocephalan cirriped
Parthenopea subterranea Kossmann, 1874
(Thecostraca, Rhizocephala, Parthenopiidae) (see
Fig. 4 d
); the parasite has already been recorded from the Black Sea ( Sevastopol Bay), but without collection data and information on host species ( Øksnebjerg, 2000 ). Copepods of the genus
Clausidium
were found attaching to the carapace and pleon on these shrimps, similar to
G. candidus
(see above). It is possible that these copepods are genus specific to the host. Unidentified scale worms ( Polychaeta : Polynoidae ) were also found in burrows of these mud shrimps.
